div.head: Peninsular and Oriental S. N. Company.
div.p: Berths can be definitely engaged beforehand. Plans can be seen at the Offices of the Company's Agents.

The through Steamers for Marseilles, Gibraltar, Plymouth and London are Intended to leave Port Said after the arrival of the 11 a.m. train from Cairo, every Monday. A steam tender will meet the train to convey passengers to the ship.
The Brindisi Express Steamer leaves Port Said directly the Indian Mails arrive. Passengers can go on board the evening before.
The express steamer usually reaches Brindisi on Wednesday afternoon, the special train starting at 8 p.m. and arriving in London at the very convenient hour of 4.56 p.m. on Friday.
The combined Sea and special train fare is £22.9.11 Port Said to London via Brindisi or via Marseilles.
Passengers having paid fall fare in one direction are allowed an abatement of 25 per cent, on returning within 12 months.
In addition to the above regular weekly service there are sailings about twice a fortnight of 5,000 to 7,000 tons steamers to London, calling at Malta or Marseilles.
TO THE EAST.

The Mail Steamers leave Suez for Aden and Bombay every Wednesday, and for Australia and China every alternate Wednesday. A steamer leaves for Calcutta, fortnightly, and another for Japan. Passengers can embark at Port Said.
For all further information apply to the Company's Agents,
Messrs. THOS. COOK & SON (Egypt) Ltd. CAIRO.
GEORGE ROYLE, Esq. PORT-SAID.
Messrs. HABELDEN & Co. ALEXANDRIA.
F. G. DAVIDSON, Superintendent P. & O. S. N. Company in Egypt SUEZ.

Express Steamers leave Alexandria every Wednesday at 4 p.m. for PIRAEUS, SMYRNA, MITYLENE, and CONSTANTINOPLE, in connection with Orient Express train-de-luxe for Vienna, Paris, and London.
PALESTINE - SYRIA LINE.

Fast steamers leave Alexandria every Saturday at 6 p.m., and Port Said every Sunday at 6 p.m., for JAFFA (for Jerusalem), CAIFFA (for Nazareth), BEYROUT (for Damascus), TRIPOLI, ALEXANDRETTA, MESSINA, continuing in alternate weeks to LARNACA and LIMASSOL (Cyprus).
RED SEA LINE.

Steamers leave Suez weekly on Wednesday at 6 p.m. for Port Sudan and Suakin direct returning from Suakin every Wednesday noon. Every Monday at 6 p.m. a steamer leaves Suez for Jeddah continuing every other week to Suakin, Massowah, Hodeidah, Aden. Intermediate steamers do not proceed beyond Jeddah but call at Tor, (for Sinai) El Wedj and Yambo as required.
N.B.—Deck chairs provided for the use of passengers, excellent cuisine and table wine free.
Steamer plans may be seen and passages booked at the Company's Agencies at Alexandria, Cairo, Port Said, and Suez, or at THOS. COOK & SON or other Tourist Agency.

div.head: S.P.C.A
div.p: The eleventh annual report of the Cairo branch of the S.P.C.A. contains muoh interesting information for the friends of animals and fall statistical tables which show the excellent work done during the past year both by the Cairo branch and by the affiliated branches in the provinces. The increased receipts show that the society is doing well from a financial point of view, the convictions for various forms of ornelty show & gratifying decrease, and the infirmary has been thoroughly repaired and rearra" ged. All these facts are in the highest degree satisfactory, but there are two points in the report that are not altogether pleasant reading for the humane: we refer to the apparent reluctance of the tourist to assist the society and to the growing practice of underpaying cab-drivers. Mr. Rambold, who has done so much for the society daring the last few years, writes on the latter subject with most commendable frankness. After pointing out that the condition of the cab-borses in Cairo during the past summer and autumn has been worse than at any time döring. recent years owing to the unusually high price of forage and the low tariff, he shows that owners of cab-horses will appropriate the same margin of profit as they have done in the days of cheap forage. The price of tibn and coro increases bat only the same amount is spent on feeding the horses.

Bat what aggravates the situation is the habit of systematically underpaying the cabdrivers, on which the Hon. Secretary of the Cairo branch of the S.P.C.A. bas much to say. The remarks which follow perhaps seem to constitute rather too severe an indictment of certain Earopeans of the higher class, bat we have good reason to know that they are not in the slightest degree exaggerated. Mr. Rambold says : "It is to be regretted that the practice of paying even less than the fare is occasionally followed by Englishmen and other Europeang of the higher class, who might be expected to know better. The argument that when the cabdriver is overpaid he will reserve the excess fare for himself, and not devote it to giving his animals more to eat, may possibly hold good in some cases ; bat, by slightly overpaying a cab driver, he is "given the opportunity of improving the condition of his ani: mals. If he is, ander-paid, he is deprived of all chance of doing so, unless he is willing to starve himself. The society have been unable to do more than arrest the worst cases and treat them at the Infirmary. Ao argument which, strange as it may seem, has been advanced in defence of paying the cab-driver less than his proper fare is' that, although the tariff is indicated on a plate in every cab, it has no legal sanction. This argument is as erroneous as it is unworthy. The cab-tariff in Csiro is enacted by the Governor of Cairo and approved by the Mixed Courts. It is, therefore, binding on foreigners, and, in the event of their paying less than the legal fare, the cabdrivers would have ground for an action in the Mixed Courts. It need scarcely be remarked that & recourse to this remedy is entirely beyond the means of the majority of drivers, who must be content to see themselves defrauded of their proper fare."

As for tourist donations, we feel that it is hopeless to expect much from these birds of passage. A few years ago, when beasts covered with wounds and sores horrified the sensitive nerves of the visitor to Egypt, donations were frequent enough. Nowadays the tourist realises that the neighbourhood of Shepbeard's and the Savoy Hotel is free from soola sights and is quite satisfied. The fact that brutalities, the sight of which would disgust and sicken bim, are too frequent in the villages and country towns of Egypt, does not intrude upon his serenely optimistic assumption that the S.P.C.A. has no further need of his help.

div.head:
OUR SPECIAL CABLES.
ALGECIRAS CONFERENCE.
INTERNATIONAL GUARANTEE DISCUSSED.
div.p: The "Echo de Paris" correspondent at Algeciras declares that the question of an international guarantee is at present being discussed in Paris, London, and Berlin by various members of the diplomatic corps. It is stated that a proposition has been forwarded by Italy in this connection. In the event of Germany acquis-cing in this suggestion the Roccors of the conference is assured, otherwise failure is inevitable.

div.head: GERMANY AND THASOS.
div.p: It has been an open secret for some time that Germany has been actively at work in the direction of obtaining from Turkey the concession of a port which could be turned into a naval station and coaling station. The Copatantinople correspondent of 'Le Petit Parisien" writes that Germany has made choice of the island of Thasos, in the extreme north of the Ægean Sea. The island was given to the Khedive Ismail Pasha, and the present Khedive is now its owner. Although the Khedive has worked the greater sart of the land and forests, he has granted certain concessions for exploiting the natural wealth of Thasos. The most important of these concassiops is one which we obtained some years ago by a syndicate of German Jews for the purpose of cutting down the timber. This syndicate was supported well by the German Government, and thanks to soch support from home it was able last year to obtain the right of working the mineral wealth of Thasos. The German Ambassador at the Porte bas demanded from Turkey the cagion of a harbour on Thasos in the interests of Germany's growing trade, and with a view to establishing thera a coaling station for the German Navy. This demand has been considered by the Porte. and rumour says that Germany will obtain the harbour which it has demanded.

div.head: GREECE AND EGYPT.
div.p: The protocol of the commercial convention between Greens and Egypt bas been drawn op and the usual exchange of signature has taken place between the Minister of Foreign Affairs and M. Napom, the delegate of the Greek Government.
We understand that the difficulties that at one time impede negotiations have been removed and that a complete settlement of all points at issue may be anticipated.

div.head: MUNICIPAL COMMISSIONS.
div.p: The Superior Council for the Municipal Commissions met on Saturday ander the presidency of Ibrahim Pasha Neghib to consider the budgets of the various Commissions for the current year.

div.head: THE SCHOOL STRIKES.
div.p: The students of the School of Agriculture have returned on being informed by the director of the granting of an amnesty by the Minister of Public Instruction. At 8 a.m. on Saturday all appeared and there is every reason to expect that after their warning they will give no further trouble to the authorities. It is to be hoped that we have how heard the last of these school strikes.

div.head: THE RAILWAY CADRES
div.p: The question of the Cadres of the Egyptian Railway Administration will be finally dealt with by the Ministry of Finance in a few days' time.

div.head: SUEZ NAVAL NOTES
div.p: The U. S. Army transporta Kilpatrick and McClellar sailed from Suez this forenoon bound to Manila.
The Coast Guard cruiser Nour El Bahr has now entered the drydock here to be overhauled, and H.H.S. Aida is running dispatches between Suez and Akaba temporarily.
H.M. transport Sicilia arrived at Suez yesterday afternoon from Bombay, and entered the Canal the same evening.
The Russian steamer Engineer Ardakoff entered the Canal yesterday evening bound for Alexandria with a tall cargo of rice.

div.head:
FASHIONABLE MARRIAGE.
KNATCHBULL-PEEL.
div.p: D.S.O., Leicestershire Regiment, to Winifred, daughter of Mr. W. T. Peel, of The Bangalow, Fleming, and Hawley Hill, Blackwater Hants, was solemnized at St. George's Garrison Church, Mustapha, on Saturday, 17th inst. St. Patrick's Day). The church was decorated for the occasion with palms and arum lilies and the service was fully choral, the music and choir being furnished by the band of the Royal Dublin Fusiliers by the kind permission of Col. Bird and the officers of the regiment. The bridegroom was attended by Captain Gordon, Leicestershire Regiment. The bride arrived at 1.45, accompanied by her father. She wore a Liberty picture gown of white satin, the corsage draped with Carrickmacross appliqué, the gift of Misa Parsons. Her court train of white silk gauze, lined with chiffon, was carried by ner piece and nephew, Ming Irene and Master Arthur Hogg, and she carried & bouquet of white roses and lilies of the valley aod wore a sapphire and pearl pendant, the gifts of the bridegroom. Hor four bridesmaids were Miss Grace Peel (sister), Miss Paraops, and the Misses Iris and Rhoda Reiss, nieces of the bride. Their dresses were white Oriental satin over mauve silk with mauve sashes and hats of tucked mauve silk trimmed with tuole of a darker shade and pink roses. They carried bouquets of Dijon roses, the two elder bridesmaids wearing gold lockets with the bride's miniature portrait and the younger ones silver moff chains with charms, the gift of the bridegroom. The little page wore & snit of white batin web three-cornered plamed bat. The bride's mother wore a Liberty giwa of soft petania satin with black hat trimmed with feathers and carried & bouquet of white roses. The hymn "O Perfect Love" was. gang, kneeling, st the commencement of the service, which was conducted by the Rev. F. Norman. Lee, chaplain to the forces, assisted by the Rav. Canon Ward, of St Mark's, Alexandria, The bridal party left the church to the strains of Mendelssohn's weddi' g march and prored ed to the Bangalow, where Mrs. W F. Peal held a largely-attended reception.

Captain and Mrs. Knatchboll left during the afternoon for Cairo for & short honeymoon and are leaving Soer tor Colombo on the 12th April. The bride's going-away dress was of silk and she wore & pietore hat of brown propoline straw trimmed with large shaded brown ostrich feathers.

div.head:
ST. PATRICK'S DAY.
ANNUAL IRISH DINNER.
div.p: On Saturday (St. Patrick's Day), the annual Irish dinner was held at Shephe-rd's and proved a thorough success. The table decorations, in which the shamrock 'figured largely, were ornamental at first and useful as the evening wore on, and the band of the 2nd Royal Inniskilling Fusiliers played a series of selections of thoroughly national character though we missed certain airs which were perhaps regarded as "party tapes."

Thirty-five Irisbmen in all were present, Johnson Pacha taking the chair, and a telegram was received early in the evening from the Innis killings in Crete wishing success to the banquet and good fortune to the Irishmen in Cairo. The Toasts of "The King," "Ireland," The Services," and "Ourselves" met with a great reception and a number of speeches were made several simultaneously.

Among those present were Johnson Paoba. Dr. Restinge. Capt. Mackenzie, Dr. Norman Capt. Evans, Dr Garner, Messrs. Langley Carren, McLoughlin, Weldon, O'Sullivan, Bewley, Young, Graves, Mackenzie, Rafferty, Duke, Kearney. FitzPatrick, de la Poer French, Brown, Debbs, Plankatt, Loftas, Roth well, Adams, Daffin, McDonnell, Delaney, Parser, Smith and Boxwell.
The thanks of all are due to Johnson Poche and to Mr. Weldon, to whose exertions the success of the banquet were mainly due.

div.head:
MINIEH EN FETE.
HORSE SHOW AND RACES.
div.p: Minieh, Saturday. Minieh yesterday was en fête In the forenoon the annual Horse Show was held at which the judging was done by a Commission including HH Prince Omar Toussoun, Ahmed Bey Bakri and Mr. Littlewood. In the afternoon, thanks to the enterprise and generosity of Omar Bey Soltan, a most successful and enjoyable Skye Meeting was held. Omar Bey has laid sat a pretty mile (ourse on his estate at Damaris, and thanks to his energy and the efforts of the hon. seo., Mohamed Bfi. Naguib, & very good entry was received for the five races of which the programme consisted. Of these, three were won by Fenwick, who had come down to ride, but undoubtedly the event of the afternoon was the race, open to gentlemen riders only, for the bandsome silver cap. presented by Omar Boy Sultan. The trophy was carried off by Mr. Boxwell on Patrick, M. Philippa finishing second. In the other events some excellent racing was seen, and the sportsmanlike manner in which all the local competitors rode augurs well for the success of future meetings. Mr. Haselden is to be congratulated on the successful manner in which he discharged the duties of starter. An excellent tea was provided by Omar Bey Sultan, and the intervals were enlivened by the local band discoursing popular air. The prizes were distributed by H.E. the Mondir, Soliman Bey Osman, and the proceedings closed with three bearty cheers for Omar Bey Sultan, who had provided 08 with such an excellent afternoon's sport. There were at least 5,000 spectators present and in addition to all the local celebrities, we noticed many visitors from Assiout, Beni Suof and the Fayoum. The police arrangements under Mr. Hopkins were excellent.

A most enjoyable garden-party was afterwards held by Mrs. Hopkins ar d Mrs. Noel Haselden at the former's house, during which Mr. Burnand delighted all present with his spirited imitations. In the evening dinner parties were given by Mrs. Hopkins, Mra. Hyeelden and Mr. Bornand.

div.head:
KHEDIVIAL SPORTING CLUB.
SUCCESSFUL GYMKHANA.
div.p: A most successful Gymkhana was held on the grounds of the Khedivial Sporting Club on Saturday afternoon. A Gymkhana is nearly always a more cheery, though perhaps a less exciting, function than an ordinary race meeting. The events with their variety of elements often have more interest in themselves, and certainly infinitely more amusement, and the presence of the fair sex as competitors on the course helps to keep alert the attention. This season, too, we have bad but few of these informal meetings, and affinity stakes, hattrimming competitions, dak competitions, and the like brought back a flavour of the East and were welcome to many for old association's zake. The attendance was very large and the interest great, as there were but few who had not some friends competing for at least one of the eight events.

Among those present we noticed Lord Edward Ceoil, Sir William Garstin, Sir John and Lady Rogers, Johnson Pacha, Mr. Webb, Mr. Carter Wilson, Lady and Miss Hemming, Cronksbank Pacha and Mrs. Crooksbank Lady and Miss Paul General: Mrs. and Miss Bullock, Capt. and Mrs. Roca Sant. and Mrs. Maclean, Col. Watson and Major and Mrs. Parsons, Capt. & Mrs. Finnegan. Capt. and Mrs. Satow, Mr. and Mrs. Knight, Capt. and Mrs. Smiley, Lady and Miss Lampson, Mrs. and Miss Pennieardie, Mr. Reid, Mr. and Mrs. Scott-Dalgleish, Mrs. and Misses Coles, Mr. Paraviciti, Mr. Robertson, Mrs. Nilav, the Mias Farrar. Mr. and Mrs. Crawford, Major Lawson, Mr. Saunders, Mr. and Mr R E Fisher, Dr. Curling Hayward, Mr. and Mrs. Masson, Mrs. and the Misses York, Mr. Adams, Mr. Kenneth Spiers, 'Mlle. Alla Zekreveky, the Misses Blyth, Mr. and Mrs. P. W. Stout, Mr. and Mrs. Nathan, Dr. Armustrong, Mrs. Trimens. Mr. and Mrs. Cranston, Dr. and Mrs. Amster, the Misses Delanoy, Miss Phillippe, Mr. Wright, Mrs. Rom, Mr and Mrs A. V. Thompson, Miss Maclnnes, Mme and Mlles. Villebois. Mrs. and Miss Whitaker, Mr. McLoughlin, the Misses Lefroy, Miss W. Sheppard, Mr. Collins, Mrs. Back, Miss Gordon Scott, Mr. Manson, Miss Cumberlidge, Mr. and Miss Párnell, Hon. Mrs. Findlay, Mrs. Gordon, Mr. and Miss Allen Joseph, Miss Osborne, Mr. and Mrs. Hatason, Mrs. George Royle, Mr. Mason, Mrs. Molenworth, Mira Wills. Mrs. Stubbs, Mrs. Mackenzie.

The next event was & half-mile race for Arabs that had never raced before in any other than gymkhana races and that had never been trained, catch weights, for which there were 12 entries. All the horses started in a bunch and there was but little to choose among them until the curve was reached, when Mr. Miller got well ahead in the straight. However, Capt. Hills, riding Major Palmer's horse, drew up and finally gained the lead and won in splendid style, Mr. Miller coming in second and Mr. Loftus a fairly good third.

The Affinity Stakes, in which a gentleman and & lady holding a ribbon between them galloped 200 yards round & post and returned to winning post without letting go the ribbon, was ron in two beats, the first two of each competing in the final. In the first beat Mr. Dalby and Mrs. Bayley ran home first, closely followed by Mr. Langley and Mrs. Molesworth, and in the second heat Capt. Rome and Mrs. Blyth ran in well in advance of the rest of the field. The final resulted in a close race between Mr. Dalby and Mrs. Mackenzie and Captain and Mrs. Rome, the former pair winning narrowly.

In the hat-trimming competition there was much amusement. In not a few cases the trimming refused to stop on the bat and some of the riders lost their hats altogether. Mr. R. E. Fischer was distinctly unfortunate in losing his horse, which got away while the bats were being trimmed and was caught with difficulty. The winner was Lieut. Mellor, with Mr. Gordop as bimilliner, and the ropner op Mr. Mason, who was partnered by Mrs. Stobbs.

Considerable excitement was caused by the dak race, in which competitors had to drive at the trot for about ¼ mile, unharness and saddle the same pony, and ride roand a post: 200 yards away, returning to winning post. Several of the horses were most restive and difficult to unharness. One broke through the railings, carrying the dogcart which he was drawing with him, and then turned it on its side, while another broke away from its trap and was not caught for some time. Mr. Mason came in first unchallenged and Mr. Langley gained second place. In the Ladies' Sourry, which consisted of a two furlongs pony race the most notable feature was the splendid riding of Miss Blyth, who came in an easy winner, though Miss Farcar also rode well and deserved the award of second place as she led the rest of the field by several lengths.

Mr. Dalby was unfortunate in not winning the Housekeeping Stakes, in which an addition arm was entrusted to ladies, as he came in first, bint the judges were unable to accept Mrs. Beyley's Addition, and the prize was therefore awarded to Mr. Akers Douglas, who came in second with a sum correctly added up by Mrs. Satow.

In the final event a lady and gentleman had to ride together, the former tilting a ring and the latter taking a peg with a sword. The award was given on the best of rounds and Mr. Protheroe-Smith and Mrs. Rome proved the winners, the former taking the peg at both rounds, and the latter carrying the ring away at the second attempt. Mr. Goodchild and Mrs. Mackenzie were also both successful at the first trial bnt in the recond round Mr. Goodchild missed the peg, though his partner again carried off the ring.
MESSRS. COVEN LACLOCHE Jewellers, beg to inform their customers that their Cairo premises will be closed for the summer season from March 31 to November 15.

div.head: ARMY AND NAVY.
div.p: In November next, Colonel G M Mackenzie will vacate the command of the 1st Battalion Royal Inniskilling Fusiliers at Belfast, under the four-years' rule. He will be succeeded by Major C. J. L. Davidson, second in command of the 2nd Battalion, the headquarters of which are at Cairo, Major Davidson is the representative of a well known Co. Derry family.

Major and Brevet Colonel C.V.R. Town sbend, C.B., D.8.0., 18t Battalion Royal Fusiliers, an officer well known in Egypt has been transferred to the King's Shropshire Light Infantry to complete the establishment, which means that in the usual course bel will get the command of the 1st Battalion. Brevet Colonel Townsend is a consig of the Marquis of Townshend, whose affairs have been before the public latterly, and he has & magnificence récord of service in the field | in Africa, India, and South Africa. He served in the Sudan Expedition, 1884-85 (mentioned, in despatches, medal with two clasps, bronze star), in the Honza Haga Expedition, 1891-92 (mentioned in despatches, medal with two clasps). --commanded the forces in Chitral Fort during its bigge, 1895 (thanked by the Indian Government, mentioned in despatches, brevet majority, O.B., medal with clasp), whilst attached to the Egyptian Army served in the Dongola Expedition, 1896 (mentioned in despatches, brevet lieutenant colonelcy, Bzyptian medal with two clasps) Nile Expedition, 1897 (clasp) Nile Expedition, 1899, including the battles of Atbara and Khartoum (mentioned twice in despatches, D.S.O., two clasps to Egyptian medal, British medal), sad was a special officer in the South African War, 1899-1900, daring the operations - in Orange River Colony and Cape Colony (mentioned in despatches, Queen's medal with two clasps). It is over 25 years since Colonel Townshend joined the Royal Marinós, in which he served five years before joining the indian Army, in which he served till 1900, when he was transferred as major into the Royal Fusiliers.

Lord Charles Beresford's report on the gunlayers' tests of his Mediterranean Fleet shows that the marines shot one round per minute faster than the seamen gunners, and that their hita were more than one round per minute quicker than the latter, and their shooting 64 per cent. better. The straightest shooting guns on the fleet were manned by marines.

Vice-Admiral F.C.B. Bridgman, M.V.O., has been appointed second in command of the Mediterranean Fleet, vice the late Sir Harry T. Grenfell. The new second in command has been 43 years on salt water, and reached fileg rank in 1903.

div.head: BRITISH SHIPPERS AND FOREIGN FREIGHTS.
div.p: At the annual conference of the Association of Chambers of Commerce held in London last week the subject of preferential treatment in regard to shipping freights was raised, and a resolution was moved by Mr. Goodman (Birmingham) That this Association is of opinion that the preferential treatment accorded by British steamship companies to foreign freights, particularly in connexion with shipments to South Africa, Australia, and New Zealand, is injurious to the commercial interests of the United Kingdom." He recommended that a deputation should wait on the President of the Board of Trade and urge the securing of equality of treatment for British shippers. Mr. Goodman pointed out that the large preferer.de given to American goods was highly injurious to British interests. He gave an instance of goods being shipped from Hamburg for Now Zealand via London at Blo, a ton, while if the same goods were manufactured in Birmingham and shipped from London' by the same steamer the freight charge for them would have been: 60s a ton. The resolution was carried.

div.head: THE SLEEPING SICKNESS.
div.p: Professor Kosh last week delivered an address at the Kaiser Wilhelms Akademie, in the presence of the German Empöror, on the subject of his investigation into the causes and the nature of the sleeping sickness in Uganda and East Africa. His studies, he stated, had entirely confirmed the results of the investigations of Dr. Castellani and Dr. Braca, and he had devoted his efforts in particular to studying the habits of the glossina palpalis, the fig by which the infection was convogel. He had found the fly chiefly on the shores of Victoria Nyanza, where it infooted a cartaia tree and was a parasite of birds. Yet, although the glossina abounded all round the coast of the lake, the sickness was mainly confined to the northern coast. The object of the second expedition which he was about to undertake was the further study of the glossina palpalis, ant of the possibility of prophylactic measures against the infection which it was the means of conveying.

div.head: KHEDIVIAL OPERA HOUSE
"ASRAEL."
div.p: I went to Asrael last night knowing nothing of the opera barring the criticisms of some scornful contrères. "They are unjust," thought I, "to youthful talent," and so saying opened the swing door and was almost deafened by an amazing clangour of cymbals which led me to fear that I had thought in baste. For the rest of the evening I repented at leisure and admired the politeness of the good people of Reggio who gave Coont Pranobetti's opera a most enthusiastic reception. The Great act was taken up by the dances of red devils armed with tridents and Lucerne hammers (such is. I believe, the name of an unwieldy compound of saw, axe, and pike which, avere the historian, I did great execution in the wars of the thirteenth century): Mephistopheles entered, smid strains borrowed from Birto, upon a huge car and after admiring some of his lady sabject, who gave a small dance on the ppt, harangued Asrael, who was shortly afterwards expelled by the infernal tridentista. The curtain fell, and after some slow music, rose to reveal a staircase going up to beajon, its bapįsters lined by angels --- who had washed, brushed and pat on new gowns since their last appearance below stairs -- trumpeters and saints of various colours all wearing aureolas, and some sporting though rather ineffective winge. Clouds of an ochreous, hue and woolly texture added to the beauty of the soene. Nefta (Signorina Ruso), the would-be saviour of Asrael, sang well here-despite an orchestral accompaniment of a jigging, creaking character that would guide the Palais de Crystal better than the New Jerusalem, and with the announcement of her resolve to save Asrael or be--I mean--lose her soul, the act mercifully ended. The next two acts were taken op with the exploits of Agrael (Sig. Langobardi), who slighted a princess, mooked a non (once Nefta); and ran Away with a buxom peasant girl (Mme. Bianca Lavin), who sang remarkably well. Despite the absence of any, thread to connect the dislocated music or the unconvincing libretto--unless I except a motif played on the big drum and cymbals in the second and on the cymbals and stage-thander-machine in the third act--Asrael's adventures were less dull than I expected. Eventually the peasant girl, after an affectionate scene beneath a rained windmill on the borders of a haunted lake and one or two duets punctuated by thunder and lightning, blew Asrael up in some mysterious way and left him dangerously wounded but singing for dear life. Eventually succumbing to loss of blood, or ichor, or flame (for I am not sure whether the flames that enveloped him as Loretta felled him to the ground did not proceed from & dagger thrass in the region of the heart), Asrael lay motionless and silent and was approached by his diabolical associates who advanced with rare caption and pretended spears, under cover of a red searchlight. A violet glow heralded the arrival of an angelic ambulance and Nefta, and I was not surprised when the last act revealed Asrael and Nefta singing in a convent court. Agrael at last renounced his amiable intention of taking Nefta home with him. Nefta declared herself unwilling to return without him, and then the deus ex machina solved the difficulty by tearing the convent into three pieces, one of which went aloft while the other two rolled to the wings and depositing Asrael at the foot of the above-mentioned celestial staircase where he was greeted by a flat bat enthusiastic chorus. "After recognising some of his old acquaintances Asrael threw off his robes (which vanished but slowly down a trapdoor) and appeared robed in white gown and golden locks. Nefta's appearance on the stairs and a shower of confetti then announced the eternal salvation of the happy pair, and had not the curtain fallen I am convinced that Azrael would haya upfurled a pair of wings despite the Horation prohibition of stage marvels. May I express the hope that the author will in future eschow opera and try his hand at pantomime, to which his talent: are probably more than equal. But I do not like pantomimes on "sacred-subjects.

div.head: THE LATE GRAND MUFTI.
div.p: The following appreciation of the late Grand Mufti in the Judicial Advisers' report is interest ing especially in view of that eminent officials outspoken criticisms of the Ministry of Justice published in "New Egypt" :--

I cannot conclude these observations on the Mehkemehs, during the past year, without alluding to the death, last July, of the eminent Grand, Mofti, the late Sheikh Møbsmed Abdon and placing on record my deep sense of the loss which this Ministry, has sustained by his demise. In all matters connected with the Sharia and the Mohammedan Courts, he was an invaluable counsellor to whose advice and good offices we constantly had recourse and the sensible and broad-minded view which he always took of religious, or semi-religious questions, was of the greatest agistance to the work of this Ministry on many occasions. Moreover the services he rendered us in the Legislative Council, in most of our recent penal and judicial reforms, in explaining and defending the views and intentions of the Government, and in seeking, when necessary, satisfactory terrain de conciliation, a basily be too highly estimated. Nor, owing to his enlightened qualities of mind, his sympathy with reforms of every kind and the special training he had had, during his years of office in the Court of Appeal, and his journeys to European cities and seats of learning, will they be easily replaced. It was to him that the Ministry had looked to organize and closely superintend the proposed Training College for Cadis, and it will be almost impossible to find anyone who possesses, in anything like the same degree, the requisite qualifications for the task.
From all these points of view, I fear that this Ministry will long have reason to deplore his loss.

div.head: FRAUDULENT ANGLO-EGYPTIAN COMPANY
div.p: At the Old Bailey this day week, before the Recorder, the trial was opened of Stewart Dixon Stubbs. Ross, 38, and George Bertram Ross, 35, of Thicket-road, Anerly, general merchants in the City, who are charged with conspiracy to defraud. The prisoners pleaded not guilty. It was alleged that the Rosses have conspired to defraud of their money persons whom they induced to become shareholders in the Anglo-Egyptian Automation Trading Company. The specific sum state in the indictment was £525.17s.6d., obtained from Mr. John George Prentios. Stewart Ross was further charged with obtaining £648 by false pretence from Mr. J. E. Champney. The company paid Mr. Mair, who prosecuted, was registered in November, 1901, with a nominal capital of £15,000, the directors being the two Ross's and a Mr. J. T. Scott. The object of the company was to manufacture, sell, and buy automatic machines for the sale of goods, and it occupied premises in Upper Thames-street and Queen Victoria-street. The company entered into an agreement with Stewart Roes to buy certain property for the purposes of the undertaking, for which he was to receive 12,005 shares. The fuct was that previously, in November, 1901, the liquidators of another company with which the Rosses were connected sold to a firm at King's Cross a number of automatic machines at the price of scrap-iron, and there were afterwards bought by Stewart Ross for £145. This was the property, it was alleged, sold by him to the company In December, 1901, the company's shares were allotted, about 14.000 going to Stewart Ross these being described as £1 paid shares. As a matter of fact no cash had been paid for them. In the course of the two following years about 800 were sold by Stewart Ross at an average price of £1.7s.6d. On representations as to the value of the company's business and as to its being taken over by another cono coat & considerable profit both Mr. Prentice and Mr. Champney bought shares. In June, 1903 a company, called the British and Colonial Automatic Trading Company was promoted by the Anglo-Egyptian to take over its business, but it was soon wound op. Later the Anglo-Egyptian Company was also wound up, the liabilities to angenred creditors being set down at £7,162. Evidence was called in support of the prosecution, and the further hearing of the case was adjourned.

div.head: THE ANGLO-EGYPTIAN BANK, LIMITED.
div.p: LONDON, PARIS ALEXANDRIA, CAIRO MALTA, GIBRALTAR, TANTAH, AND PORT SAID.
The Anglo-Egyptian Bank. Limited, undertakes every description of banking business on the most favourable conditions.
Current accounts opened with commercial homes and private individuals in conformity with the custom of Bankers.
Fixed deposits for one year certain received at 8 per cent. per annum. Deposits at interest for shorter periods are also received at rates to be agreed upon.
Letters of Credit for the use of travellers are issued payable in all parts of the World.
Approved bills discounted.
Bills, documentary invoices, etc, collected.
Drafts and telegraphic transfers issued payable all over the World.
Foreign exchange bought and sold.
Advances made upon approved securities and upon cotton, cotton-seed, sugar and other merchandise.
The purchase and sale of stocks and shares on the London Stock Exchange; and on the local and Continental Bourses, undertaken.

Customers can deposit their valuables, bonds, etc., for safe custody in the Bank's fire-proof strong-rooms, and the Bank will attend to the collection of the coupons and drawn bonds so deporited as they fall due.
Mercantile credits issued.
Annuities, pensions, dividends, etc., collected.
All farther particulars and information can be obtained on application.
The officers and clerks of the Bank are pledged to secrecy as to the transactions of customers. 18-9-905

div.head: Dépôt de Marque de Fabrique
div.p: La Société Anonyme Égyptienne dénommée "Tabacs et Cigarettes Matossian," a déposé aux Greffes Commerciaux de Tribunaux Mixtes da Caire et d'Alexandrie, sons les datag TeAppetives don 4 et 20 Jsovior 1906, one série d'étignettes nouvelles, destinées à être apposées paquets de tabacs.
Les procès-verbaux de ces dépôts ont été publiés in extenso dans le Journal Officiel (Numéros da 20 Janvier et do 10 Février 1908)

Lesdits dépôts, ainsi que la présente publication, ont pour objet d'assenza la Société Anonyme soussignée la propriété exclusive et absolue dag dires marque de fabrique, et de prévenir toute contrefaçon.
Ils n'ont Inent sortina 'enonciation, de la part de la Société, aux tér Oto on érienremant effectués par elle aos mêmes Graffes.

Soriété Anonyme. Alexandrie, le 10 Mars 19/6.

div.head: Daíra Khassa de S.A. Le Khedive
AVIS
div.p: La Daira Kbaşga de S.A.lė Khédive à l'hon neur d'informer le Public qu'elle met en vente aux enchères, une manche a benzing nommée Edfinah ayant les caractéristiques suivantes:
Longueur 5 mètres et 85 centimètres. Largeur 1 mètre soignante centimètres, Proue quarante ou q centimètres. Poupe soixante dix centimètres.
Vitesse à l'heure 10 Kilomètres.
Los personnes qui désirent concourir à l'achat de la dite mouche pourront la visiter à l'Argent des Bateaux Khedivial (Boulac).
Les offre devront être présenté sons plis cacheté adressées à son EXCELLENCE LE DIRECTEUR GÉNÉRAL DE LA DAÏRA de 8.A. LB KHÉDIVE et accompagnées d'un cautionnement de !0% ad valorem.
La Daïra procèdent le 20 Mars à 10 heures da matin à l'ouverture des offres ! taire devra payer en comptant le bolde dê ainsi que tous autres frais éventuelle.
La Daïra se réserve le droit d'adapter ou de figer l'offre la plus élevée et même de ne donner aucune suite à l'adjudication sans que les soumissionnaires puissent avoir aucun recours contre Elle.

div.head: Circulaire H. de Vries et Boutigny
NOTES ET CRITIQUES
div.p: Le Caire, le 17 mars. A Londres, lo Consolidé anglais a regagné bier 1/8 à 30 1/2 L'Unifiée a réactionné de 1/4 à 105 3/4. La National Bank est renseignée en hausse de 3/4 & 28 7/8. La Daïra est restée in variée à 18 1/8. L'Agricole a encore gagné 1/8 # 97/8.
A Paris, l'action Crédit Foncier Égyptien a réagi de 4 francs à 791. La Banque d'Athènes est en nouvelle reprise de 1 frano & 149.
Notre marché" a été, ce matin, fort animé avec tendance généralement ferme.

La National Bank a haussé jusqu'à 28 1/2 l'action ancienne pour o'tarer å 28 1/4; l'action nouvelles avancé & 27 5/16. L'Agricole s'est inscrite à 9 3/4. Poursuivant son mouvement ascensionnel d'hier, la Cassa di Sconto a encore gagné 10 francs à 225;la nouvelle émission a fait 222,

L'action Crédit Foncier est restée à 791 ; l'obligation 1886 a fléchi à 381. L Daïra s'est maintenue 18 1/8. L'action Immobilière à réactionné à 395 et la part de fondateur à 675. L'action Land Allotment est revenue à 41/16 et la part de fondateur à 160. Les Sucreries ont repris à 26.
L'action d'Entreprises Immobilières et Tra. vaux est remontée à 41/4; la part de fondateur qui a eu les honneurs de la matinée, & bond. de 10 à 15, acheteure, regagnant cinq livres en une séance.
L'action privilégiée Tramways d'Alexandrie & avancé & 169; les dividendes à 830. La part de fondateur Menzaleh & encore baissé de P.R. 10 à 180.
Dans le groupe des Hôtels, les Nangovich ont faibli à 17 1/2. Les Baehler se sont inscrita à 5 15/16 et les Upper Egypt 5 1/2.

Parmi les petites valeurs, les Glymenopoulo, en bonne tendance, ont fait 1 1/2 acteurs. Les New Egyptian ont coloré à 37 ; les Delta Land à 8 9/16-518; les Hooker & 1 1/8; les Cold Storage & 0 8/4 et les Cotton Mills à 7 sh. 3.
Un de nos correspondants nous transmet les observations suivantes, qu'on trouvera absolument justes ;

"Il est extraordinaire qu'on calonne fort simple ait échappé jusqu'ici à la perspicacité non seulement des spéculateurs en général, mais même des hommes de Bourse en particulier. Il s'agit du bénéfice réalisé en "arbitrant" des Hooker contre des Delta Land, aux prix actuels des deux titres.

"Du moment que cinq actions Hooker doivent être échangées contre une action Delta, il y a, co me semble, tout avantage à acheter des Hooker pour les troquer contre des Delta Land. En effet, 6 Hooker à £1 1/8 (moins 10 sh. non versée) reviendraient à £31/8, alors que la Delta Land est à £8 5/8. Ce serait donc un profit assuré d'une demi-livre par chaque achat de 5 Hooker.

"Aussi bien ceux qui vendent leurs Hooker rappellent l'histoire du fellah, peu confiant, heureux de se débarrasser d'une banknote de L.E. 1 de la National Bank pour s'assurer 80 piastres en monnaie d'argent."

La hausse remarquable ani s'est produite récemment sur les actions Omnibas da Caire semble-être appelée à s'accentuer. On annonce, en effet, que le décret autorisant définitivement le service d'omnibus automobiles au Caire et dans diverses villes de l'intérieur paraîtra lundi prochain.

La Compagnie des Omnibus en profitera' pour mettre, parait-il, on service ano centaine de voitures, dont 64 an Caire. Ces voitures, dont le nombre sera augmenté par la suite, desservent les quartiers indigènes les européens encore dépourvue de moyens de transport économiques.
Ce sera, comme on voit, presque on second service de tramways appelé à assurer à la Com. pagnie des recettes magnifiques.

Un journal d'Alexandrie fait remarquer que la réaction qui s'est dessinée ces jours derniers sur les titres de la Société d'Entreprises Immobilières et de Travaux est due uniquement au fait que le conseil d'administration a décidé de faire effectuer le deuxième versement de L.B. 1 par action. "C'est là - dit ce journal - âne de ces petites dépressions qui se produisent invariablement sur les actions de toutes les sociétés chaque fois qu'il est fait en appel de fonds. La valeur réelle du titre et de l'affaire n'en demeure pas moins iñtacte. Il y a même ton lien de s'attendre à ce que cal cours favorables aient pour effet d'engager les acheteur sérieux à s'intéresser au titre."

A l'assemblée générale du chemin de ser Ke neh-Assouad, tenne le 12 da courant, il a été décidé de distribuer: 1° un intérêt et dividende. de de P.R. 110. 25 par action de capital ; 2° on dividendo de P.E. 42 par action de jouissance, et on dividende de P.R. 78. 75 par part de fondateur, payables à partir du 20 mars à la National Bank of Egypt.
Los cours du coton sont arrivés en nouvelle hau88e d'Amérique. Hier le disponible et le Mai ont gagné respectivement 10 points et l'Octobre 7.
Les arrivages ont été dg 32,000 parigos contre 22,000. . Le marché de Liverpool est également, en reprise.'
Ioi, le Mai, qui a fini hier soir à 20 1/4, a ouvert ce matin à 20 1/2 pour clôturer à 20 13/32.

div.head: BULLETIN DE LA BOURSE
div.p: (Aujourd'hui à midi et demie) La ba 088e de l'Urbaine que nous ne cessions d'indiquer s'est produite ce matin. Dès l'oc. verture le cours & taché le prix de 6 9/16, pour actionner graduellement à 6 7,16 en oltaire, ce qui n'en constitue pas moins une avance de 5/16 sur le cours de samedi. D'importantes réalisations ont eu lion.

Les valeurs de traction que nous avons recommandées, commencent à bouger. Les Trams S'avancent à 180 len privilégiées et à 340 les dividendes. On prévoit ainsi un mouvement prochain sur la Ramleh dont les recettes augmentent dans de fortes proportions.
De 6 5/8 la Comptoir monte à 6 3/4. La part de topdateor clotore a 42.
En revanche le Crédit Foncier réactionnel à 835 et les Nungovich 4: 17 3/8, sang beaucoup d'affaires:
Le cours de l'Oasis demeura toujours nominal à 1 1/2, par saite de l'absence de vendeurs.
Une bonne demande s'est produite en l'investment, ce qui a poussé le cours à 6 11/32-8/8 acheteurs. Une baisse est en perspective sur, cette valeur,
Très ferme la Delta Light clôture à 12 1/2 et l'Agricole à 9 7/8, en excellente tendance.

div.head: THEATRE ZIZINIA
div.p: Le Dédale qui est sans conteste un chef d'oeuvre du théâtre contemporain, a obtenu or vif succès samedi soir.
L'ouvrage d'Hervieu, qui est un éloquent plaidoyer contre le divorce, réforme des scènes poignantes qui ont été fort bien rendues par ces artistes incomparables que sont M. le Bargy et Mme Baraty.
Hier soir on a donné "On ne badine pas avec l'amour," et "Une nuit d'Octobre" d'Alf. de Masset.
Le rôle de Perdican, dans la première pièce, est un de meilleurs da répertoire de M. le Barsy, et laia vala le ler prix au concours da Conservatoire.
Ce soir "Le Réveil," ot "l'Énigme" d'Hervieu.
